text: I cant tell if this movie was lackluster or catered to a specific age group. The books initially came out nearly 30 years ago, I'm aware there was a rerelease but even with that, it just seems off. It plays it very safe, it struggles to find an identity by juggling stories that come and go too fast for you to really invest anything into them. Theres a strange series of subplots, or pieces of plots, political, social, racial... they're relative to the setting but dont seem to play any significance. They're just floating around...allowing for any scene to grab one and insert it into the moment but seemingly for no reason. The cast played their roles well but their characters were hollow and random. It had vibes similar to IT(the reboot), but it doesnt give us any intamate scenes with the characters like IT does. I remember reading the books, so I was super eager to see them come to life, but they didnt seem "scary." They looked great, but behaved like amateurs and relied on some jump scares to really bring them home. I'm down with some jump scares, but I'm torn because I think it's a case of " getting old." It seems great for younger audiences but I also feel it could have done a lot more with more time. IT has plenty of young fans, but the films are also like "epics." Theres just not enough here for a horror fan to sink their teeth into. But it's still worth a watch, even if just for nostalgia...

text: So just saw this movie. Surprisingly much better than I thought. It actually delivered on some serious scares. Used tension to really build up to effective jump scares (as opposed to just throwing a jump scare out of nowhere). The cinematography is beautiful too. Incredible colors and angles. My big complaint is the monsters are these comically stupid cgi things. They look super creepy far away, but up close and I couldn't help but laugh. There's also some pretty awful, melodramatic acting at the end. All in all though, definitely a step above most mainstream horror. Definitely recommend. üëçüèº

text: Honestly the vibe I'm getting from this trailer is that Guillermo made this movie purely for his own gratification. Like he did this for fun. It's not meant to be taken seriously in the same way as how campfire ghost stories are meant to be scary but also a bit silly.  And I think that's what makes it good, because you go into the movie theater with the attitude that you're just there to have a bit of childish fun. Too many horror movies nowadays take themselves way too seriously and it just comes across as try-hard and pretentious. And in the end, even if you did get a couple of decent scares, you didn't really actually fully enjoy yourself.  This seems fresh and different. I'm going to watch it.

He gets freaked out and sells it. A few years later he goes by the guy he sold the horse to and asks if he can see her. The horse died and her pile of bones lied in the corner of the field. He's relieved because now he knows there's no way the horse could kill him, he finds the horses bones and mourns for a moment, he decides to take the skull, and when he reaches down to get it a rattlesnake jumps out of skulls eye and bites him. text: As a 90s kid/horror genre fan who loves and still owns my original set of Scary Stories to tell in the Dark books from my childhood, here's my honest opinion: *This movie sucked monster balls!* Why'd they have to do it like this? It could've been so great! They basically took the plot from the 2015 goosebumps movie (finding a book containing the stories, which when opened then become reality) but then failed to incorporate *anything* related to any of the Scary Stories plots. No, what they did was hold a few glimpses of Scary Stories characters over the head of us nostalgic fans of the original books, luring us in with the promise of a long awaited homage to a beloved childhood horror series. Once you excitely pay your ticket and walk into the theater, expecting to love/ or at least like it, you'll soon realized that what you were actually given was a spit to the face. What should've been a decent movie turned out to be another pile of crappy preteen horror flick. This movie was built on lies and cliches! The plot was made up and cliche, the characters were cliche, the (jump)scares were cliche, it was nothing BUT cliches! Oh you people who grew up with the source material thought it was for _you?_ Lol no, it was for the kids and _your money._ I had faith in you Guillermo del Toro! I expected better! I gave you my trust, and this is how you _repay me_ üò¢üíî? And to anyone wondering what stories are *(poorly, some just simply mentioned)* used in this film, it's:  The Big Toe What Do You Come For? Me Tie Dough-ty Walker! The Hearse Song The Haunted House The Wendigo Harold The Dream The Red Spot There, hopefully I'll be saving you the money that I had wasted, and if you do decide to still go see it, come back here so we can be disappointed togetherüò§. In the meantime, I'll just be revisiting my Scary Stories books, staring at Stephen Gammells haunting imagery until it chases away the bad memory that was this film.

text: Scary Stories To Tell In The Dark is my favorite book ever! This movie  looks like it will be good but its very hard to match the magic that  Alvin Schwartz and Stephen Gammell created. I would have liked the film  in black and white for starters and I am not too convinced about the  plot. Scary Stories was protested and banned for its violent stories and grotesque illustrations if this film isn't twisted and horrifying then  it won't do the book justice. Guillermo del Toro is awesome so I will  keep an open mind and enjoy the film nonetheless.

text: This trilogy of books means SO much to me...my mom would read stories to our class at the elementary school Halloween parties (especially the jump stories!) The illustrations are, well, legendary. I've now got an awesome tank top with a bunch of them print-screened all over because I'm evil. My love of scariness basically began with these books, Goosebumps, Are You Afraid of the Dark?, and Beyond Belief: Fact or Fiction. That's the core. >8-] I'm sure this movie'll be fun, although...I was hoping for a Creepshow-style anthology of as many stories as they could fit in to tell. This kinda looks like a combination of the Goosebumps movie (scarier than that though) and, like, a Stranger Things aesthetic (80s kids...) There was supposed to be a documentary film all about the books coming out as well, which I had backed on Kickstarter...wondering what happened to that, actually. Anyways, I hope this movie includes as many of the stories from all three books as possible...there are tons.

Real talk these book messed with my braid hard as a kid, the drum story made me think my mom would abandon me, and the hotel one made me scared to leave my mom alone in case she died and ppl tried to pretend she didnt exist like I never had a mom in the first place, and my boi harold out here roasting ppls flesh in the sun so nuff said.

text: This should be a show but framed like an anthology the scary stories were all their own thing ..the red spot was so creepy the scare crow the way the stories painted a stark creepy gloomy picture and built up the horror..this feels too much like what they tried to do with goosebumps..looks cool as its own thing but each story deserved its own movie honestly guirmo should have broken this up and let the stories unique individuality connect through our relatable fears of the unknown..i dont think mashing them all together using the book as a 4th wall breaker to tie everything into a short story was the best idea..not to take away from the value of the potential of this work ..still looks creepy and scary though another thing is capturing the essence of the grotesque distorted nature of the artflow ie. Red spot the girl was more creepy looking black long stringy hair the face distorted it really added to the visual appeal and mood this looks a little hurried

text: Ah, yes, The BEST part of the books where the Black and White water color inked illustrations gave an uncertain ethereal element to each picture. They where like as if they weren't just printed in the book, but painted on the vary pure white canvas of a child's imagination. Just like the ink-blot of the Rorschach test, to an adult, it's just a picture. To a child, you could "feel" the image existed deep in your mind, like a suppressed memory, "it" was there. "IT" was staring, not only at you, but INTO your very being, because "it" is a part of you. "It" is your fear drawn out in black ink, and you swear, no you KNEW that "IT" JUST MOVED!!!!!  (It would be hard to capture that magic and put it into a movie, but I can't wait to see it.)

text: I‚Äôve read both goosebumps and Scary stories to tell in the dark. Goosebumps wasn‚Äôt going for a horror. I think it was more of suspense, and mystery. I don‚Äôt recall ( it‚Äôs been years since I read the books) goosebumps ever having murder or death. It was a clean version of scary stories with twists and not happy endings. Kid friendly if you will. SSTTIND however was more of a Edgar Allen Poe for kids. These were stories that actually were about horror, and bone chilling terror.  I do have high hopes for this movie and the Fear Street movie from r.l. Stine. Soon as I had finished goosebumps, I went to the Fear Street series!

text: Stories mentioned in the trailer in order of appearance: Harold (skinned 1 victim, the victim obviously died) The Curse (mentioned, when they get to the house they said kids went missing, it is not shown if anyone went to the third floor) The Big Toe (death not shown in the source material) The Dream (harmless) The Attic (no monster, but a guy gets a foot full of nail) The Cat's Paw (no death, but the witch gets a foot shot off) The Red Spot (death not shown in the source material) Me Tie Dough-ty Walker! (dog dies, human death not shown in the source material) The jangling man (doesn't exist, as far as I know, maybe one of the monsters that don't kill someone and is never shown)   I have a theory that the book was found before, considering Harold exists and the events of the Curse already happened.

text: I am literally sitting next to my copy of the trilogy i got back in school.  I am freaking out. Like there were pages that were bookmarked because they were TOO SCARY and you needed to know they were coming. The art was actually done by a regular children's illustrator and it was the only time he drew anything dark like that.  Just his magnum opus....and the publishers have since found out that their book is ultra-frightening and have replaced the art with some watered-down lukewarm trash.  God bless Del Toro for attempting to give the tales the macabre essence that was stripped away.

text: To all the people making the "Goosebumps" comparisons, let's set the record straight: "Scary Stories" were released in the 80's, the Goosebumps books were products of the 90's. It's kind of a "Generation X childhood" vs. "Millennial childhood" thing. This is the "old school" children's horror books! Also, I'll never forgive "Goosebumps" for taking over the slots on the store bookshelves where the "Choose Your Own Adventure" books were stored. "CYOA" went away as the 90's progressed, and they were replaced by Goosebumps! And also by "Animorphs" books, as the 90's went on...me, I preferred "CYOA" and "Scary Stories"...

text: Can someone help me remember the name of this story? text: I like that the monsters look just like they did in the original. But also, They weren't just Monster books. One of favourite stories Was called I think The Room Number? A girl and her mother check in at a Paris hotel, The mother grows ill (it doesn't seem too serious) and sends the girl to fetch some medicine from a doctor in the next town over,  on her way to the doctors she realizes that the cab she's in has been driving in circles. and they're still about 2 hours away. They finally get there and the Doctor invites her in, he goes on for some time about mundane things. She asks him about the medicine and avoids the question, yet again, she finds herself wasting time and staying there several hours longer than she needs to be, the Doctor finally gives her the medicine,  its now nighttime, so he offers to let her stay until morning, when getting a cab will be easier. She declines and calls a cab, only for one to show up hours later. She finally gets on her way and realizes this cab is also driving in circles, growing frustrated and desperate to get this medicine to her mother,  she jumps out and makes her way to Paris by morning, when she arrives at the hotel she finds (I Think) the name of the hotel has changed, when she goes in, she sees the same employee. Who claims to have never seen her before. None of the staff claim to have seen her before and there's no record of her or her mother checking in. She goes to the room only to find the decor completely changed and her mother nowhere to be seen. The story ends there but the excerpt at the back of the book claims that what we don't know is that while she was out her mother died of the plague and to keep the city from panicking, they simply sent people to stall her and keep her away for as long as possible. When she gets back,  they simply erase her mother from history, leaving her confused and alone.   Could be recounting the story incorrectly, as I've not read it for about ten years.

text: Back in the 90s I went through a serious Stephen King phase. I read a lot of his books voraciously. I remember IT was the one that scared me the most ( I'll never forget the Kitchener Ironworks part ). I remember being in line at B. Dalton Bookseller one day waiting to buy Nightmares & Dreamscapes and looking at the Halloween display up at the register which had a lot of spooky books. I Immediately noticed Scary Stories To Tell In The Dark because of the awesome artwork on the cover. I bought it on a spur of the moment along with my other book and I was so glad I did. Those creepy little stories have haunted me for years AND NOW HERE THEY ARE COME TO LIFE!! Can't wait to see this movie.

text: As excited as I was for this movie, this trailer has ruined a lot of my expectations. While I understand they‚Äôre trying to be different and create this world full of familiar monsters it just seems cliche and does not respect the original writing. When Tales From the Crypt did their movie, it was put into different stories from the comic books. That‚Äôs how I personally feel is should of been done. Take the best stories and make a two hour movie out of it, make a sequel, and there you go. I‚Äôm really disappointed that they decided to go this way, but hopefully I‚Äôm wrong and they‚Äôll still be able to make an interesting story out of it.

text: I am so excited to see this movie in theaters. When I was a kid, there was a small corner of the library filled with dust and cobwebs and among those books was a simple, frayed black book with no title on the cover or the spine. That was the book that me and my friends would dare each other to check out and read at night, hiding under our blankets with a flashlight and wondering if that creaking sound in the¬†hallway was The Thing or a nightmare creature looking for it's big toe!¬†To say it left an impression is an understatement, these stories have always been a huge part of my childhood and I cannot wait to see the movie when it's released in theaters. Yes, I'm letting the nostalgia drive me, but I couldn't be happier!

text: I think something like this would work better either as a series, or anthology format. It would have helped distinguish it from any other horror movie right now, while also remaining faithful to the source material. The overall mood doesn't exactly fit with the books either, which present an atmosphere of impenetrable gloom and dread.  But whatever, a bunch of teens finding a spooky book. Let's do it.   I think this movie will be not terrible, but ultimately forgettable.
